data.question: What is the chemical formula of MOF-150?
What are the secondary building units (SBUs) used in the synthesis of MOF-150?
What is the symmetry of the interpenetrating frameworks in MOF-150?
What is the ratio of trihedral to hexahedral tiles in the pyrite net?
What is the transitivity of the pyrite net?
What is the significance of the pyrite net in the context of MOF-150?
data.answer: It is identified as the default structure for the assembly of triangles and octahedra.

data.question: Why is the pyrite net considered more regular than the rutile topology?
data.answer: Because the pyrite net has a higher symmetry with transitivity 2112 compared to rutile's 2232.

data.question: What role do the solvent guests play in the structure of MOF-150?
data.answer: They fill the space remaining after interpenetration in the crystal.

data.question: How are the SBUs in MOF-150 produced?
data.answer: By employing previously determined reaction parameters to effect their formation in situ.

data.question: What is the result of heating MOF-150 at 10 °C min-1 in air from 30 to 700 °C?
data.answer: A weight loss step at 240 °C corresponding to the loss of all guest molecules.

data.question: Is MOF-150 the first example of a fully catenated structure with mixed coordination?
Does MOF-150 have the same topology as the high-pressure form of PdF2?
Are all rings in the pyrite net 6-rings and related by symmetry?
Do the two interpenetrating frameworks in MOF-150 have different symmetries?
Is the default net for a given connectivity always the one with the highest symmetry?
Does the synthesis of MOF-150 involve heating a mixture in a quartz tube under vacuum?
